results.title: Daylight saving sleep schedule
results.brief_description: They say it takes a village, and the village it seems has moved online, with countless parental bloggers dishing out advice for desperate parents - many of whom are exceptionally sleep deprived. @jampikelets offers a moment of reprieve, with his hilariously honest posts making light of the early years of baby raising. And there is nothing more daunting than a daylight savings transition to unnerve parents everywhere. 4am start anyone?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

They say it takes a village and the village it seems has moved online with countless baby bloggers dishing out advice for desperate parents - many of whom are exceptionally sleep deprived. @jampikelets’s video satirises the plethora of social media posts offering parental guidance while also poking fun at relationship dynamics to hilarious results. A welcome reprieve to many daunted by an upcoming daylight savings sleep transition. 4am start anyone?
description_for_label: They say it takes a village and the village it seems has moved online with countless baby bloggers dishing out advice for desperate parents - many of whom are exceptionally sleep deprived. @jampikelets’s video satirises the plethora of social media posts offering parental guidance while also poking fun at relationship dynamics to hilarious results. A welcome reprieve to many daunted by an upcoming daylight savings sleep transition. 4am start anyone?

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Bill McIntosh]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Beam Software programmer, Bill McIntosh, left a boring job in the Royal Air Force to join Beam after his wife bought him a computer, which he equates with “plugging in his brain”. He discusses the games he worked on and the culture at Beam, and the financial conditions in Australia that put such companies at risk.

results.title: [Royal District Nursing Service TV Ad]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

This television advertisement is an appeal for donations to the Royal District Nursing Service. Filmed in black and white, the advertisement shows a nurse visiting various patients in the community, including babies, the elderly, disabled and blind. A voiceover describes the valuable contribution the nurses make to the community, with over 300,000 visits per year - enough patients to fill the largest public hospital.

results.title: An Interview with Peter Clemence
results.brief_description: Peter Clemence tells us his experience in the Royal Australian Air Force at the end of the Second World War, his experiences flying scientists in Antarctica in the 1950’s and his adventures flying helicopters during the mining exploration era. He also talks about Ash Wednesday and the collapse of the West Gate Bridge.

results.title: My life to study
results.creator_credit: Fei Hu Song, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Fei Hu Song and his family came from China to Australia, they all took English language courses. This began for Hu Song a lifetime of study and of making Australia his home.

results.title: Waiting to laugh
results.creator_credit: Hamid Naemi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Now settled in Australia, Afghani born Hamid reflects on the difficult and lonely times he and his sister experienced when they moved to Iran after their mother’s unexpected disappearance and their father’s death one year later.

results.title: Running to stand still
results.brief_description: Adrian Bush tells the story of how, after spending most of his life on the move, he found friendship and a sense of belonging playing street soccer in Fitzroy, Melbourne, with others from the Big Issue team. Adrian was selected for the Australian street soccer team, which toured internationally, and appeared in an ABC documentary. His experiences with the Big Issue and street soccer have transformed Adrian’s life.

results.title: A Colour Box
results.brief_description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.
description_for_label: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.
